SafetyInspectionBy: Iowa Department of Agriculture & Land Stewardship

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

FOR FURTHER INFORMATION CONTACT:LARRY SCHULTE, LOCATION MANAGER

I. THE FACILITY POLICY

   A. THE OWNER, MANAGEMENT, AND EMPLOYEES OFCROPMATE COMPANY, ODEBOLT,  IOWA ARE COMMITTED TO THE PREVENTION OF ANY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA. IF AN ACCIDENTAL RELEASE SHOULD OCCUR, THE FACILITY IS PREPARED TO WORK WITH THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT, LEPC, OR OTHER AUTHORITIES, TO MITIGATE ANY RELEASE AND TO MINIMIZE THE IMPACT OF THE RELEASE ON PEOPLE AND THE ENVIRONMENT.

II. FACILITY INFORMATION

  A. THE PRIMARY ACTIVITY AT THE FACILITY IS THE STORAGE AND HANDLING OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA IN NURSE TANKS FOR SALE TO FARMERS. THE MAIN STORAGE TANK FOR THIS OPERATION IS LISTED UNDER A PREVIOUSLY SUBMITTED RMP. THE STORAGE TANK IS LOCATED ON A SEPERATE PIECE OF PROPERTY. THIS RMP COVERS ONLY THE FACILITYS PROPERTY WHICH IS APPROXIMATLEY ONE BLOCK FORM THE MAIN FACILITY. A  NUMBER OF THE NURSE TANKS ARE STORED ON THIS PROPERTY IN THE OFF SEASON. THIS NUMBER VARIES FROM ZDERO TO ONE HUNDRED NINE 1,000 GALLON TANKS. 

   B. ANHYDROUS AMMONIA IS RECEIVED, STORED, AND DISTRIBUTED FOR APPLICATION ON CROPS AS FERTILIZER NUTRIENT.

   C. THE MAXIMUM QUANTITY STORED WOULD BE WOULD BE 4,378 POUNDS IN A 1,000 GALLON NURSE TANK. *NOTE: MAXIMUM QUANTITY ALLOWED TO BE STORED IS 85% OF NURSE TANK SIZE. THE MAXIMUM AMOUNT OF PRODUCT ON SITE WOULD BE 477,148 POUNDS IN ONE HUNDRED NINE 1,000 GALLON NURSE TANKS.

III. THE WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND THE ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO

   A. THE WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO WOULD BE THE RELEASE OF THE TOTAL CONTENTS OF A NURSE TANK OVER A 10 MINUTE TIME SPAN. THE MAXIMUM QUANTITY RELEASED WOULD BE 4,378 POUNDS, WHICH REPRESENTS THE VOLUME OF THE TANK AT 85% CAPACITY AS LIMITED BY DESIGN STANDARDS. THE DISTANCE TO THE TOXIC ENDPOINT (POINT OF DISPERSION TO 200 PPM) IS 0.31 MILES. 

   B. THE ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO IS BASED ON A RELEASE FROM A BREAK IN A TRANSFER HOSE. THE DISTANCE TO THE TOXIC ENDPOINT IS 0.22 MILES.

IV. THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE, PREVENTION PROGRAM

   A. THE FACILITY HAS IMPLEMENTED THE PROVISIONS OF THE SAFETY REQUIREMENTS FOR THE STORAGE AND HANDLING OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA, K-61.1, PUBLISHED BY THE AMERICAN NATIONAL STANDARDS INSTITUTE INC.

   B. THE FACILITY HAS IMPLEMENTEDTHE STANDARDS OF THE U.S. OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH ADMINISTRATION (OSHA) 29 CFR 1910.111, STORAGE AND HANDLING OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA.

V. THE FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

   A. THERE HAVE BEEN NO ACCIDENTAL RELEASES OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA THAT HAVE CAUSED ANY DEATH, INJURIES, OR SIGNIFICANT PROPERTY DAMAGE AT THE FACILITY, NOR HAVE RESULTED IN OFF SITE DEATHS, INJURIES, EVACUATIONS, SHELTERING IN PLACE, PROPERTY DAMAGE, OR ENVIRONMENTAL DAMAGE. 

VI. THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

    A. THE FACILITY HAS A WRITTEN EMERGENCY ACTION PLAN, IN ACCORDANCE WITH OSHA STANDARD 29 CFR 1910.38. IN THE CASE OF AN UNCONTROLED RELEASE, LOCATION PERSONNEL WOULD NOTIFY AUTHORITIES AND EVACUATE. EMPLOYEES HAVE REVIEWED THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM  INCLUDING PRE-EMERGENCY PLANNING AND EMPLOYEE TRAINING

  B. THE FACILITY HAS PROVIDED TO THE STATE AND LOCAL AUTHORITES, THE EMERGENCY PLANNING AND COMMUNITY RIGHT-TO-KNOW INFORMATION AS REQUIRED UNDER SARA TITLE III (EPCRA).

 C.  THE LOCATION IS WORKING WITH LOCAL AUTHORITIES TO BE INCLUDED IN THE COMMUNITY EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN. 

VII. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

   A. SAFETY IMPROVEMENT IS AN ONGOING PROCESS AT THE FACILITY. PERIODIC EVALUATIONS ARE PERFORMED TO ACCESS THE MAINTENANCE OF SAFE CONDITIONS AND EVALUATE EMPLOYEE TRAINING. THERE ARE NO SPECIFIC ANHHYDROUS AMMONIA SAFETY RECOMMENDATIONS AT THIS TIME.
